channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 29 August
item.description: The number of new cases in the community is still in double figures, with the government set to confirm tomorrow whether Auckland can drop to alert level two.

item.title: Earlier closing hours can reduce alcohol harm - health experts
item.description: Public health experts are calling for earlier closing times for bars and shops selling alcohol after tracking a substantial fall in the number of young people hospitalised due to assaults after 24-hour sales ended.

item.title: Damaged baby food pouches discovered in Countdown stores
item.description: Countdown has issued an alert after a small number of damaged baby food pouches were found in some stores.

item.title: 'Quacking from a drain': Ducklings rescued from Auckland motorway
item.description: Police officers and firefighters teamed up to rescue almost a dozen ducklings from a deep drain in the middle of one of Auckland's busy motorways today.

item.title: Covid-19 update: 11 new community cases, two in managed isolation
item.description: New Zealand has 11 new cases of Covid-19 in the community today, with Auckland due to drop to alert level two tomorrow night.

item.title: Petition urges Pharmac to fund Crohn's and colitis medication
item.description: Thousands of people are backing a petition to improve the lives of hundreds of New Zealanders with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

item.title: Rain fills Aucklandâ€™s dams, but hose ban stays
item.description: Auckland's water reservoirs have nudged above 66 percent full, but water restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Lessons people can learn from Covid-19 lockdown: 'Live more lightly on the planet'
item.description: In a world struggling to cope with Covid-19 and climate change looming over its shoulder, are New Zealanders looking for ways to become more self-sufficient? Leith Huffadine reports.

item.title: Covid-19: Group looks to import Russian-made vaccine
item.description: Former National Party leader Don Brash says he is willing to help bring an unproven Covid-19 vaccine to New Zealand, because it is of enormous importance.

item.title: Covid income relief payment recipients fare better than those on the dole, survey finds
item.description: People on the 12-week Covid income relief payment are faring better than those on the benefit, new survey data shows.

item.title: Personal air sanitisers an explosive hazard on planes - CAA
item.description: The Civil Aviation Authority is warning passengers that products marketed as personal air sanitisers are an explosion hazard on aircraft.

item.title: Covid-19 precautions keep sailors on ship
item.description: Crew on a container ship who are desperate to spend time ashore in Dunedin have been "blindsided" by extra Covid-19 precautions.

item.title: Auckland's second lockdown 'nail in the coffin' for some businesses
item.description: Auckland businesses that struggled to attract customers while the City Rail Link was constructed nearby are now hoping customers will return when the city shifts to alert level 2 on Monday.

item.title: Hamilton-Auckland commuter train service delayed to early 2021
item.description: The service had been scheduled to get begin on 2 November, but had to be delayed for urgent track work to be carried out by KiwiRail.

item.title: Two dead after two crashes overnight
item.description: A road in Northland is temporarily closed after a woman died in a car crash, while another person has died following a crash involving a pedestrian in Tasman.

item.title: Magnitude 5.2 quake hits East Coast
item.description: People on the East Coast south of Auckland were jolted awake by a 5.2 magnitude earthquake early this morning.

item.title: Van Gogh art becomes multi-sensory outdoor exhibition which opens in Wellington
item.description: The life and work of Vincent van Gogh is the subject of a brand new multi-sensory outdoor exhibition opening in Wellington tonight.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 28 August
item.description: With 12 new cases reported in New Zealand today, Finance Minister Grant Robertson has thanked Aucklanders for their commitment as the end of level 3 restrictions nears.
